title: Monday, 25th September, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:02am

Morning

PM11:02am

Aftermath of the German elections

PM11:02am

Dax up 0.1%

11:02 am
PM11:03am

German 10 year at 40 bp

PM11:03am

So that's dull

PM11:03am

Snap election called in Japan

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Actually, I don't think we've ever had Abe up here

PM11:03am

Which is a shame, given our ownership

PM11:03am

And something we should correct

11:03 am
PM11:04am

PM11:04am

Moody shot, eh?

PM11:04am

Implications of the Japan election -- not sure

11:04 am
PM11:04am

He's way ahead in the polls

PM11:05am

That's enough politics, tho

PM11:05am

And we're going to ignore Trump and the NFL

11:05 am
undefined
PM11:05am

Bryce -- let's try and make something of London movers

PM11:06am

Yes, I know the Footsie drifting

11:06 am
PM11:06am

17 points or so

PM11:06am

Mixed -- very mixed

PM11:06am

Suppose we can fall back on Friday night's news

11:06 am
PM11:07am

Imagination

BE11:07am

We can. Rather late Friday.

Imagination Technologies Group PLC (IMG:LSE): Last: 166.06, up 37.56 (+29.23%), High: 178.00, Low: 164.25, Volume: 22.64m
11:07 am
BE11:07am

Came out at nearly 10pm on a Friday night, which isn't ideal for newspaper printing schedules.

BE11:08am

The news is pretty much as expected though, though the price is slightly on the high side of expected.

PM11:08am

Did we expect this structure?

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Yep.

PM11:08am

To try and avoid getting blocked?

PM11:08am

ok

11:09 am
BE11:09am

To recap, this is Canyon Bridge, the China-backed PE thing that was blocked from buying Lattice, paying a pretty punchy looking 182 pence per share for the old Videologic.

PM11:09am

https://canyonbridge.com/

BE11:09am

The company that used to do chips in set-top boxes, and then the Dreamcast console, and then about a decade ago got lucky and managed to put itself in some Apple toys.

11:10 am
PM11:10am

(I notice Canyon Bridge still got the Lattice deal on their website as ' news' as tho it is going to happen)

BE11:11am

(.... I guess there's a formal process to go through there. We're not quite at a point where President Dingwad can say "let's block this" and it just happens.)

BE11:11am

So ..... as I say, good price, full auction, relatively bombproofed structure by spinning off MIPS.

11:11 am
PM11:12am

Actual takeover here https://www.invest...1709250700026334R/

PM11:12am

And MIPS here https://www.invest...1709250700326397R/

BE11:12am

Stuff in the press in the leadup about Imagination being a test of the govenment's protectionist chops is probably nonsense, because ..... well, I mean, it makes graphics chip IP.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

What are the Chinese meant to threaten here?

BE11:13am

Might they add red flags to Candy Crush? I mean .... anyway, have some sellside. Here's JPM Caz.

BE11:13am

We see deals announced to sell MIPS to a US VC firm and the graphics business to a Chinese financial firm as attractive to the investor base, in particular the value obtained for the graphics business which is well ahead of value obtained for similar businesses in the past or based on current prospects of the business. Thus the high value must be a function of the value the buyer places on using the technology to new uses such as Artificial Intelligence/Machine Learning which has also substantially increased value for graphics companies NVIDIA and AMD. At the same time, despite working to separate businesses into US and non US, we do not know if the deal will indeed escape CFIUS and/or UK government scrutiny.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

The most interesting sidebar in all this is perhaps that we now have the Chinese in a legal fight with Apple.

PM11:14am

Ah yes, of course

BE11:14am

The iPhone teardowns have started arriving, by the way: https://www.ifixit...e+8+Teardown/97481

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Though they don't really tell us much about whether the new proprietary Apple graphics thing is squatting on Imagination IP.

BE11:15am

Back to JPM ......

BE11:15am

IMG highlighted that its dispute with Apple (regarding the payment of royalties for IMG IP) is ongoing and may or may not result in a settlement. In case a settlement with Apple is reached, IMG would be entitled to return capital of up to 50% of the excess amount (defined as the settlement amount less the value in respect of Apple taken into account by Canyon Bridge in determining the offer price) either as an interim dividend or other distribution avenues, without there being an adjustment to the terms of the offer.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

I'd suggest a quick resolution there is a distant possibility, though maybe Apple could buckle early and pay some of its humongous cash pile just to avoid fighting with Beijing. Who knows?

BE11:17am

Here's Alphavalue.

BE11:17am

[W]e consider the whole offer rather reasonable, as the premium is consistent with the nature of Imagination’s technology, i.e. potentially a very high margin business, and in any case a very qualitative asset in a sector that has dried up by the massive M&A wave in the past two years; however, some work will need to be done by the acquirer following the loss of Apple, Imagination’s main customer, and this 182p offer remains barely a third of the 2013 peak.

11:17 am
BE11:18am

We consider it is rather unlikely that another player will raise the stakes: the company has been up for sale for some time already, and the rumours have favoured Canyon Bridge since the beginning.

BE11:18am

The biggest risk is actually political: Canyon Bridge is a Chinese company and has just seen its acquisition of Lattice semiconductor, a US company, blocked by Mr Trump. So this will be a test for Mrs May, in the context of Brexit, but we actually don’t see what could be done to block the deal, as the UK doesn’t have the equivalent of the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States. It is therefore likely that Imagination will suffer the same fate as ARM, i.e. going under a foreign flag.

PM11:18am

Are there any guesses as to what an Apple settlement might be worth per share?

11:19 am
PM11:19am

Would have thought it's quite difficult to price all this

PM11:19am

Political risk on both sides of the pond in the mix

PM11:20am

Wouldnt blame people for taking the 166p on offer right now

11:20 am
BE11:20am

I haven't seen anything particularly useful for the potential Apple settlement, which I suspect reflects the improbability of it arriving before this is all done and dusted.

BE11:22am

Just scanning back archive to find a value ......

BE11:24am

........... bah, not a single analyst I've found has put a £ value on the possibility of a deal.

11:24 am
PM11:24am

Fair enough. It would be pure guesswork in any case

undefined
BE11:24am

Tullow also moving .............

11:24 am
Tullow Oil PLC (TLW:LSE): Last: 188.80, up 10.5 (+5.89%), High: 192.90, Low: 187.40, Volume: 10.88m
BE11:25am

............... again on non-today news.

PM11:25am

From the International Tribunal of the Law of the Sea

11:25 am
BE11:25am

That's the one. The Maritime Border thingy has ruled that TEN is entirely in Ghanaian waters.

BE11:26am

Which means, firstly, that Tullow can get on and actually produce some oil ......

BE11:26am

.... and secondly, it can move on from being a dull old oil company and turn back into an explorer.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Which is apparently what investors want. Apparently.

BE11:27am

Stifel has a fair summary of the thinking here, as part of an upgrade.

BE11:27am

A positive outcome from the Ghana-Cote d'Ivoire ITLOS tribunal removes a key downside risk and with high-impact, seemingly low-risk exploration upcoming, we think the risks and potential reward are now well balanced. Tullow remains on a strong multiple of cash flows, our preferred metric for valuing highly leveraged companies, so we upgrade to Hold from Sell, target price unchanged.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

So ...... it's a driller again.

BE11:28am

Here's the catalyst list.

BE11:28am

Araku being the big one ......

11:28 am
BE11:28am

In Guyana, or Suriname, or possibly both. I forget. Check the archive. We mentioned it last week I think.

BE11:29am

Back to Stifel ......

BE11:29am

Which I'll screencap because their PDF's playing up.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

PM11:30am

Hey, on the TEN ruling, there's a map!

BE11:30am

Thumbs up

11:30 am
PM11:30am

PM11:30am

Ivory Coast must be a bit sore

BE11:31am

I can see why the International Tribunal of the Law of the Sea took approximately 15 years to draw that map. Complicated business.

11:31 am
undefined
BE11:32am

Seems we're talking supermarkets on the right.

BE11:32am

Aldi numbers. Sales up and margin down.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

As in, margin hit of 90 bips.

BE11:33am

To 2.4% for the full year.

PM11:02am

Welcome to Markets Live

11:35 am
PM11:35am

But Aldi still taking market share?

BE11:35am

It is, because sales growth of 13.5%, which is ahead of what the sector watchers were expecting by extrapolating Kantar etc.

BE11:35am

Let me get some Bernstein.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Profit drop implies action taken by Tesco is working. In our view the profit drop reflects the success Tesco has had, in particular with Farm Brands during 2016. This has put pressure on pricing in Aldi's core product range and encouraged customers back to Tesco. At the same time as Aldi's margin dropping, Tesco is able to put pressure on Aldi's core range while increasing its own operating margin.

More compromise on the discounter model may be driving costs up. Aldi announced a £300m investment programme to increase space for fresh, chilled and food to go. In addition to installing improved fixtures and brighter, wider aisles. These are features we would more traditionally associate with a supermarket than a discounter and suggests they are expanding growth by moving away from a pure discounter model. These improvements being made will not be cheap and help to explain why margin is falling. We would expect a further margin drop in 2017 to pay for these enhancements.

BE11:36am

I guess the good news for the listed players is that the expansion plan isn't being accelerated.

BE11:36am

Instead, cash -- £300m of it -- is going on perking up stores a bit.

11:36 am
PM11:37am

Never been in an Aldi, must confess

PM11:37am

I went in a Lidl on Sunday -- on the old kent road, while I was waiting to get one of the kid's iphones fixed. Sheesh. It's a real third world experience.

BE11:38am

I like that jumble sale aisle in the middle where they sell leather skirts, ukuleles and chainsaws.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Anyway, no particular response from the sector.

Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 184.15, up 0.3 (+0.16%), High: 184.70, Low: 182.65, Volume: 1.93m
J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 234.01, up 0.712 (+0.31%), High: 234.90, Low: 232.40, Volume: 1.05m
11:38 am
WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 233.93, down 0.775 (-0.33%), High: 234.90, Low: 233.30, Volume: 720.91k
BE11:39am

So we won't overdo the coverage.

undefined
11:39 am
BE11:39am

Actually, while on retail though.

Next PLC (NXT:LSE): Last: 5,175, up 35 (+0.68%), High: 5,204, Low: 5,125, Volume: 87.35k
BE11:40am

Geoff Ruddell of Morgan Stanley went into town at the weekend, and comes back bearing worrying news.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Next appears to have gone on sale over the weekend. This is very unusual for Next at this time of year, which is renowned for holding only two full sales a year (one in July and one after Christmas).

BE11:41am

He notes that Next's July summer sale was poor, and the company has said as much, so this might just be clearance of whatever tat is left from that.

BE11:42am

Nevertheless this doesn't seem to be a great sign for a company whose shares have bounced more than 40% since Mid-July on the basis that the outlook is improving....

11:41 am
BE11:42am

Nope.

undefined
PM11:43am

What else?

11:43 am
PM11:43am

Stobart down on a directors selling

PM11:43am

On friday

Stobart Group Ltd (STOB:LSE): Last: 272.40, down 12.2 (-4.29%), High: 285.20, Low: 271.90, Volume: 374.14k
11:43 am
PM11:44am

But there's no other news there that i can see

BE11:44am

Ditto. There's not much volume in Stobart

BE11:45am

As in, any day, not just today. So I guess we can pin it on Friday's sale.

11:44 am
undefined
BE11:45am

ITV mentioned.

BE11:45am

Wouldn't it be great if the story were anything other than "advertising buyers make positive noises"?

11:45 am
ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 169.65, up 3.35 (+2.01%), High: 170.30, Low: 165.50, Volume: 5.63m
BE11:46am

Unfortunately, the story is "advertising buyers make positive noises."

BE11:46am

Here's Liberum.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

ITV (BUY, 330P TARGET PRICE). We upgrade our FY17E ITV TV NAR forecasts to -2.5% from
-4.5% on the back of what looks like a relatively good September and our expectations of
a flat Q4. This drives a 4% FY17E adj. EPS upgrade and increases our target price from 320p to 330p. Our confidence is driven by signs that some previously weak sectors such as FMCG may be coming back and positive comments on the market generally. If consensus upgrades do come through, we expect a re-rating in the shares. We also expect ITV to be able to strike a much improved retransmission deal with Virgin Media, partly due to ITV1 carriage fees, but also due to the improved performance of its secondary channels. Reiterate Buy.

BE11:47am

We also had Bazalgette at the Royal Institute of British Architects talking ads.

BE11:47am

"People in the media-buying business are reporting a slightly improving situation," he said.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

"We’ve had 2 years where the ad market has been down, last year and this year, and we’ll wait to see."

BE11:47am

Which is nice.

undefined
11:47 am
PM11:48am

Seen this huge stuff Morgan Stanely's done on robotics?

PM11:48am

Ive only read part of it -- but they have some conference coming up on teh matter as well\

PM11:48am

Process Automation - Transforming and Disrupting Process Delivery

11:48 am
PM11:48am

Next month

BE11:48am

K.

PM11:49am

The good news is that it's bad news for certain outsourcers

11:49 am
PM11:49am

Or so MS say

PM11:49am

Robotic Process Automation is a game-changer for the way company processes are executed. Outsourcing Services revenues and contract lengths should fall and customer self-sufficiency increase. We see a $25/60bn hit to global Business Processing Outsourcing and IT Services markets, medium term.

PM11:49am

What is RPA? Robotic Process Automation is a piece of software often referred to as a robot. It sits 'on top' of systems taking information from one and feeding it into others - work that is currently being conducted by humans. The easiest way to think about it is as an 'Excel macro on steroids'. Cognitive takes RPA further by learning from a human worker when there are discrepancies and then applying the observed judgement to complete a process.

11:49 am
PM11:49am

Real world examples of RPA ... Many of us will have had to cancel a lost or stolen credit card. The process seems relatively straightforward to us - we call our credit card hotline and speak to an operator to cancel the card. However, the process for the bank will often be much more complex as it has multiple back-end systems that are not integrated. In our example, the bank employee who takes the call needs to collect the data and then input that data into a number of back-end systems - one to cancel the card, one to order a new card for the customer and a third to check what spending has taken place since the card was lost / stolen. With RPA, this entire process can be automated and the Bank staff reallocated to more value-added work. In a real life example, software robots were deployed to take the initial information from the customer and then place that into the three back-end systems. A 25 minute process previously became almost instant and the bank saw a 6x productivity improvement - as well as lower card fraud rates as reported cards were cancelled more quickly.

PM11:50am

… and cognitive enhanced RPA. When we add cognitive to RPA, rather than following simple instructions to move data from x to y, the software robot will be trained over time and learn from its mistakes so it can complete more complex tasks. An example would be a train company that used cognitive RPA to refund customers automatically when trains were delayed. The software robot was used to work through emails from customers and after training was able to recognise the key meaning and sentiment of the mails. It could also recognise customer information and activate the refund. This automation reduced the time and headcount required to process the mails by 85%.

PM11:50am

Why is it important? RPA is fundamentally transforming how processes are executed. Adoption is growing exponentially driven by very compelling economics: one RPA robot can do the work of three to five workers (one provider suggests this could be as high as 15 working on a fully-utilised basis) and most industry players estimate the level of cost savings, based on full time equivalent (FTEs) time, is 10-25%, which can rise to 30-50% with cognitive enhanced RPA. Proof of concept can take 3-6 weeks, deployment 3-4 months and the return on investment (RoI) can be just 3 months.

These virtual workers don’t sleep or make mistakes and operate in a compliant manner. In addition, the simplicity of the technology enables customers to 'do it yourself' (DIY self-sufficiency model) and bring processes back in-house. The business case is always based on FTE savings, but the benefits also include freeing up employee time for more value-added functions. In addition, there are obvious quality gains, which can improve business outcomes for companies and even customer service levels. Early adopters are the insurance and banks industries, but RPA's end-market application is across multiple processes in numerous industries.

11:50 am
PM11:50am

We see automation driving major changes in BPO as companies insource and share shifts from vendors back to in house delivery. Business process outsourcing takes a complete business process (e.g. collecting a receivable or managing a customer service centre) and hands it over to a third party. We believe that the main driver of BPO was cost reduction, especially as the process was often also offshored to a low cost location.

Automation will be a major force in leveling the playing field in the IT Services market as automation further reduces the advantage offshore players enjoyed. We do not see any one vendor having a significant advantage in the automation world and believe that the willingness to invest in and deploy these technologies will be key. The company that can drive automation the most quickly - and at scale - will win the most market share, in our view. The only advantage we would see at the outset is that companies already operating at larger scale could have an advantage as their returns on automation investment could be higher - and of course they will likely have more resources to invest.

PM11:50am

Let me get you the accompanying bubble chart

PM11:51am

11:51 am
PM11:51am

Last par

PM11:51am

What are the investment implications? We flex the bear case and see potential for EBIT to fall 5-35%. We believe that RPA will fundamentally change the business model for BPO. Most industry participants agree that contract values will come down, contract lengths shorten and there is material scope for self-sufficiency. In IT Services, we believe automation can level the playing field further between onshore and offshore vendors after a c. 20-year period where offshore based vendors have enjoyed a competitive cost advantage. We do not expect the same scale of insourcing in this market. As a result, we believe onshore vendors that can build automation into their offering could see a benefit in the short to mid term and we see EBIT rising 4% and 2% for Atos and Capgemini on a 5-year view. However, in the long term, we see automation as a negative for revenues and profits for the entire industry. We see a potential bear case of EBIT falling from 5% to 35% for companies under our coverage on a 10-year horizon. While this is a long-term potential impact, we could expect to see a derating sooner; impacts from previous structural changes derated the affected companies by 31% on average.

PM11:51am

Genpact and Capita seen as being hardest hit -- in time

11:51 am
undefined
BE11:52am

(@Mouselet: I think the answer is, "Blue Prism spends a lot on PR".)

BE11:53am

So ........... what else? Not a lot in the way of corporate.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

There's NMC, the current holder of the "FTSE 100 company people care least about" award.

BE11:53am

Which is in part because there's hardly any free float.

NMC Health PLC (NMC:LSE): Last: 2,677, up 4 (+0.15%), High: 2,704, Low: 2,645, Volume: 145.43k
11:54 am
PM11:54am

They have some Saudi deal -- is that right?

BE11:54am

They have, two deals for $40m.

BE11:55am

One, a 60% stake in a 100 berth in Najran, the other a 60 berth in Hail, which is going to be a 100 berth shortly.

11:56 am
BE11:57am

Plus some other stuff. Approval of a long-term-care thing in Jeddah, a greenfield in Al Khobar .... it's all pretty exciting stuff if you're excited by stuff about Middle East hospitals.

BE11:57am

Here's Citi.

BE11:57am

The CCSMC and Al Khobar newsflow will
not impact consensus in our view. However, the $40m payment consideration suggests an EBITDA uplift to NMC in the low-to-mid single-digit $m’s (based on likely EV/EBITDA multiples). We model $429m/$228m of FY18f EBITDA/attributable earnings for NMC, so the net positive impact to consensus EPS/EBITDA should not be far from 1%. We currently model FY18f Net Debt of $732m, equal to 1.7x EBITDA, and thus the transactions will not materially change the balance sheet position.

11:57 am
BE11:58am

..... meanwhile, as to the FTSE 100's other play on Middle East hospitals (plus some other stuff) .....

Mediclinic International PLC (MDC:LSE): Last: 658.50, down 22 (-3.23%), High: 674.50, Low: 656.50, Volume: 301.78k
BE11:58am

Jefferies selling.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

We lower LT EPS by 8%-10% as update for Spire’s recent profit warning impacting associates and take a more cautious stance in Switz. due to reassessing TARMED. We continue to believe the market is likely to be disappointed at the 1H trading statement (Oct 17) and results (Nov 16) and believe the UAE is yet to trough which is likely to disappoint the bulls. Our ‘19E EPS is c.9% below cons. PT lowered to 550p. Retain Underperform.

BE11:59am

Dubai Competition is increasing; Parkview is a large investment: With pressure likely continuing in Abu Dhabi, we expect competition to intensify in Dubai. Incremental capacity coming on-stream is also likely to lead to further competition, particularly for general hospitals which we believe could impact MDC’s City hospital. Furthermore, MDC acquired land on the Umm Suqeim Road Al Barsha and the company commenced building
the Parkway hospital in 2016 with a view to creating 188 general beds (incl. cardiology, ER,
Maternity and NNICU); we note the ramp is to impact profitability which we believe the bulls are underestimating.

BE11:59am

EPS lowered by 9%; we continue to be below cons: Our UAE EBITDA forecasts are c.5% below cons in ‘18E and c.15% in 2019E as we continue to believe the recovery will be gradual. At the group level our 2018E EPS are 5% below cons in ‘18E (9% in ‘19E) which we expect to disappoint the bulls at 1H despite a 2H weighted year in the UAE. We also now take
a more cautious stance on Switzerland fully reflecting anticipated TARMED pressures and
Hirslanden 2020 costs. We also see a mid-term risk that day cases are increasingly viewed in an outpatient setting. MDC plans to focus operationally to counter these pressures. We expect lower margins in 2019 with the full TARMED hit and expect an update at 1H.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

So ........ there we have it.

undefined
PM12:00pm

Thin for a Monday.

11:59 am
PM12:00pm

But thanks for that Bryce

PM12:00pm

And for everyone on the right... Come along to the RabbleFest on Wednesday

PM12:00pm

12:00 pm

PM12:00pm

It will be fun

PM12:01pm

But we are done for today

12:00 pm
PM12:01pm

PM12:01pm

Bye

BE11:34am

This is a response to Tesco cutting prices with its Farm Whatever range, because for all its promotions and PR pushing there's still a perception that cheap is all Aldi has.
